message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cocaine withdrawal symptoms usually include decreased appetite, fatigue, and dysphoria. Option B is incorrect because cocaine withdrawal leads to decreased sympathetic stimulation. Option C is incorrect because lacrimation is a symptom of opioid withdrawal. Option D is incorrect because seizures are not a common symptom of cocaine withdrawal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cocaine withdrawal symptoms include fatigue, decreased energy, increased appetite, and psychomotor retardation. Of the options, only (A) increased appetite is listed as a possible symptom. Increased sympathetic stimulation may occur during cocaine use, but it is not a withdrawal symptom. Lacrimation and seizures are not typically associated with cocaine withdrawal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cocaine withdrawal symptoms vary but increased appetite is a common symptom due to the drug's suppression of appetite. Increased sympathetic stimulation is a symptom when a person uses cocaine. Lacrimation is not typically associated with cocaine withdrawal. Seizures are possible but less common in cocaine withdrawal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cocaine withdrawal can cause increased appetite, depression, and lethargy. Increased sympathetic stimulation is a symptom of acute cocaine use, not withdrawal. Lacrimation and seizures are not commonly associated with cocaine withdrawal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Withdrawal from cocaine can cause increased appetite, but not increased sympathetic stimulation or lacrimation. Seizures can occur but are less common than increased appetite.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cocaine withdrawal symptoms include increased appetite, depression, and fatigue. Increased sympathetic stimulation and lacrimation are acute symptoms of cocaine use, not withdrawal. Seizures can occur in severe cases of withdrawal, but it is not the most common symptom.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cocaine withdrawal can cause decreased appetite, not increased appetite. Increased sympathetic stimulation, lacrimation, and seizures are all potential symptoms of cocaine withdrawal, but the question is asking for the incorrect option.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cocaine withdrawal symptoms typically include fatigue, depression, anxiety, and decreased appetite. Increased sympathetic stimulation and lacrimation are acute effects of cocaine use, not withdrawal. Seizures are a rare but serious potential complication of cocaine withdrawal, but not a common symptom.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cocaine withdrawal can cause increased appetite, but it is also associated with symptoms such as fatigue, depression, anxiety, and increased craving for cocaine. Option (B) is incorrect because withdrawal causes decreased sympathetic stimulation. Option (C) is incorrect because lacrimation is a symptom of opioid withdrawal. Option (D) is incorrect because seizures are rare in cocaine withdrawal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Withdrawal symptoms from cocaine use include increased appetite, fatigue, and depression. Increased sympathetic stimulation is a symptom of acute cocaine intoxication. Lacrimation and seizures are not listed as common withdrawal symptoms.
